resources.string: View Accessibility Techniques
Home
Android View Accessibility Techniques Demo App
This application demonstrates a variety of accessibility best practices for View-based UIs, as well as the problems they can address.
Use the cards below to pick a topic area and follow the directions on the screen regarding the assistive technology employed in that demonstration.
Accessibility Basics
Grouping and Ordering
Dynamic Behaviors
Specific Component Types
Show details
Text alternatives
Provide text alternatives for non-text content when appropriate

All informative non-text content must have a text alternative associated with it, generally via the contentDescription property. Purely decorative content that conveys no meaning must be marked as such with either a null contentDescription or importantForAccessibility=\"no\".
Informative non-text content that is redundant with adjacent text content should be grouped with that text content. See examples 3 and 4 below.
Turn on TalkBack and read the screen elements for examples.
Bad example 1: Sunrise and sunset times and icons without text alternatives
OK example 2: Sunrise and sunset times and icons with text alternatives
Sunrise
Sunset
Good example 3: Sunrise and sunset times grouped with their icons
Note that all example headings on this screen use a similar technique.
Good example 4: Sunrise and sunset times and icons with group text alternatives
Sunrise at 6:24am
Sunset at 5:35pm
Bad example 5: A \'Share\' icon button without a text alternative
Share icon without text alternative clicked.
Good example 6: A \'Share\' icon button with a text alternative
Share
Share icon with text alternative clicked.
Bad example 7: Decorative images without any contentDescription
Example decorated text.
Bad example 8: Decorative images with text alternatives
Sprout
Example decorated text.
Good example 9: Decorative images with null contentDescription
Example decorated text.
Good example 10: Decorative images with importantForAccessibility=\"no\"
Example decorated text.
Input field labels
Associate labels and input fields programmatically
Turn on TalkBack and swipe through this page to hear demonstrations of input controls with and without programmatically associated labels.
Bad example 1: EditText without associated field label
Field label not associated with EditText
Good example 2: EditText with associated field label (labelFor)
Field label associated with EditText
Good example 3: TextInputEditText automatically associates hint
Associated field label/hint
Bad example 4: CheckBox without associated field label
Field label not associated with CheckBox
Good example 5: CheckBox with associated field label (text)
Field label associated with CheckBox
Bad example 6: Switch without associated field label
Field label not associated with Switch
Good example 7: Switch with associated field label (text)
Field label associated with Switch
Bad example 8: RadioButtons without associated field labels
Field label not associated with RadioButton
Second field label not associated with RadioButton
Good example 9: RadioButtons with associated field labels (text)
Field label associated with RadioButton
Second field label associated with RadioButton
Good example 10: Button with associated text label (text)
Button label
OK example 11: Slider with contentDescription and no labelFor
Slider label
Slider content description
Good example 12: Slider with contentDescription and labelFor text
Slider label
Slider content description
Good example 13: RangeSlider with contentDescription and labelFor text
Range slider label
Range slider content description
Tap target grouping
Group nearby tap targets that perform the same operation
If two tappable elements perform the same operation and are in visual proximity, they should be combined to form a larger tap target with a common description.
Turn on TalkBack and swipe through this page and activate the tappable controls to see examples of uncombined and combined tap targets.
Bad example 1: Ungrouped tap targets
App information
App information
Note how ungrouped tap targets can read redundantly, as well as creating more, smaller selection areas.
One of the ungrouped example tap targets was selected.
Good example 2: Grouped tap targets
App information
Note how grouping the tap targets creates a larger TalkBack tap target and fewer tap targets overall.
The grouped example tap target was selected.
Dark theme
Support both Dark and Light themes

Some visual disabilities are alleviated by using light-on-dark or dark-on-light styling. Support the user\'s selection of Dark theme or Light theme by using a DayNight application theme and supplying dark theme colors with sufficient contrast. See Dark theme for more details.
Refer to res/values/themes.xml, res/values/colors.xml, and res/values-night/* for how Dark theme is implemented in this application.
In the device Settings app, select Display and then enable or disable Dark theme. Observe the effects on this app.
Device orientation
Support all device orientations
Some devices are operated in fixed orientations and cannot be rotated to an app\'s preferred orientation. Therefore, both landscape and portrait layouts must be designed and supported.

Supporting all device orientations involves not locking any activity\'s device orientation in AndroidManifest.xml, making screens scrollable, supplying landscape layouts in res/layout-land when appropriate, and retaining application state across device configuration changes.

In this application, no landscape-specific layouts are supplied, so the portrait-mode layouts are used in all orientations. Application state is retained across configuration changes using ViewModels, but other approaches are available; see Handle configuration changes for more details.
Rotate the device to landscape-left, portrait, and landscape-right orientations and observe the effects on this app.
Content grouping
Some content should be grouped for screen readers

Some text, particularly in simple tables, cards, and list items, should be read as single block by a screen reader, even when the content consists of separate TextViews. This enables a screen reader user to skip to the next content block instead of hearing each text separately. If a card or list item is clickable, this is handled automatically; otherwise, it should be done manually.
Turn on TalkBack and listen the following items for a demonstration.
Simple table examples
Bad example 1: Ungrouped table
Bad example 2: Misgrouped table
Good example 3: Properly grouped table
City name
Population
Area (sq mi)
Boston
Card examples
Bad example 4: Card without grouped content
First Author
January, 2014
This card does not group its content for screen readers. Note how you have to swipe through each separate TextView.
Good example 5: Card with grouped content
Second Author
March, 2020
This card groups its content for screen readers using importantForAccessibility=\"yes\". Note how a single swipe takes you to the next card.
Good example 6: Another card with grouped content
Third Author
This card groups its content by being clickable (and focusable).
Activating a card would normally open a detail view of the card\'s content.
Content group replacement
Grouped content can be replaced to enhance screen reader experience

Sometimes the graphical components of a layout group do not convey their meaning well to screen readers, even if grouped into a single text. In this case, replace the screen reader text for the layout group with something better.
Turn on TalkBack and listen to the items on this page for a demonstration.
Bad example 1: Rating with content ungrouped
Bad example 2: Rating with content grouped
Good example 3: Rating with grouped content replaced
Rating:
Reviews: %1$d

plurals.name: content_group_replacement_rating_group_content_description
plurals.item: Rating: %1$s out of %2$s stars, based on %3$d review
Rating: %1$s out of %2$s stars, based on %3$d reviews

resources.string: Heading semantics
Heading text must be marked as an accessibility heading
Accessibility headings both convey the semantic meaning that text is a heading to a screen reader user and allow heading navigation in screen readers.
Turn on TalkBack and read the following text for examples. Switch TalkBack to use the Reading Control \"Headings\" and swipe down and up to experience heading navigation.
Bad example 1: Big text that is not a heading
Graphically large text won\'t act as a heading for accessibility purposes by itself; it must be marked as a heading.
Bad example 2: Ending contentDescription with \'Heading\' is not a heading
Bad example 2: Ending contentDescription with \'Heading\' is not a heading, Heading.

Marking a View with a contentDescription that appends \"Heading\" to the text does not give that View accessibility heading semantics. The large text above might announce "Heading" in TalkBack, but it is not recognized as having that role by the TalkBack "Headings" Reading Control.
Good example 3: Two accessibility heading techniques
Views can be marked as accessibility headings in XML layouts in API 28 and up with android:accessibilityHeading=\"true\".
To support earlier versions of Android, use ViewCompat.setAccessibilityDelegate on the View and set AccessibilityNodeInfoCompat.isHeading to true.
List semantics
Mark visual lists with accessibility list semantics

Lists created with ListView and RecyclerView automatically provide list semantics to accessibility services like TalkBack, reading things like “in list” / “out of list” and “1 of 5.” However, visual lists created with LinearLayout need to have list semantics added via the Accessibility API.
Turn on TalkBack and swipe through this page to hear demonstrations of visual lists without and with list semantics applied.
Bad example 1: Visual list without list semantics
Bad example, Point 1
Bad example, Point 2
Bad example, Point 3
Bullet. Bad example, Point 1
Bullet. Bad example, Point 2
Bullet. Bad example, Point 3
Text after a non-semantic visual list.
Good example 2: Bullet list with list semantics
Good example, Point 1
Good example, Point 2
Good example, Point 3
Bullet. Good example, Point 1
Bullet. Good example, Point 2
Bullet. Good example, Point 3
Text after a semantic bullet list.
Good example 3: Numbered list with list semantics
Good example: Numbered list with list semantics
1. Good numbered example, Point 1
2. Good numbered example, Point 2
3. Good numbered example, Point 3
Text after a semantic numbered list.
Good example 4: RecyclerView list with list semantics
RecyclerView example, Point 1
RecyclerView example, Point 2
RecyclerView example, Point 3
Text after a RecyclerView list.
Good example 5: Non-list RecyclerView without list semantics

RecyclerView controls that do not present visual lists should suppress list semantics. This technique is often needed in the case of dynamic server content that does not appear as a list, but requires a RecyclerView implementation for memory or performance reasons.
Breakfast
Cereal
Source: Will Kellogg
Great food for breakfast, or any time. Just add milk.
Oatmeal
Hot food; mixes well with dairy or dried fruits
Source: Henry Seymour
Dinner
Last meal of the day, unless you count midnight snacks
Text after a RecyclerView without list semantics.
Focusable, clickable controls
Set android:focusable=\"true\" and use onClickListener, not onTouchListener

Some versions of Android require non-focusable elements, like ImageView, to set android:focusable=\"true\" in order to be focusable by the keyboard or an accessibility service, even when they are touchable or clickable. Prefer default-focusable controls like ImageButton.
If an element uses an onTouchListener, it will not be activatable by either the keyboard or an accessibility service. Use an onClickListener instead.

Tap any \"+\" icon to see a snackbar. Use Switch Access to select all active controls and activate them. Use a Bluetooth keyboard to Tab through the page also, focusing and activating each control. (You may need to scroll the view to locate focusable icons.) Note which icons are focusable and activatable with each method.
Bad example 1: Non-focusable ImageView with onTouchListener
Tap me!
Example 1 ImageView with onTouchListener tapped.
An ImageView with onTouchListener is not focusable or activatable with keyboard or Switch Access. It does not announce as actionable in TalkBack, but does activate on double-tap when selected.
Bad example 2: Focusable ImageView with onTouchListener
Tap me!
Example 2 Focusable ImageView with onTouch handler tapped.

An ImageView with onTouchListener and android:focusable=\"true\" is focusable using the keyboard, but not with Switch Access. It is not activatable with the keyboard or Switch Access. It does not announce as actionable in TalkBack, but does activate on double-tap when selected.
Bad example 3: ImageButton with onTouchListener
Tap me!
Example 3 ImageButton with onTouch handler tapped.

An ImageButton with onTouchListener is focusable using the keyboard and Switch Access, but it is not activatable with either. It announces as actionable in TalkBack, but does not activate on double-tap when selected.
Good example 4: Focuable ImageView with onClickListener
Click me!
Example 4 ImageView with onClickListener activated.
An ImageView with android:focusable=\"true\" and onClickListener is focusable and activatable using the keyboard, Switch Access, and TalkBack.
Good example 5: ImageButton with onClickListener
Click me!
Example 5 ImageButton with onClickListener activated.
An ImageButton with onClickListener is focusable and activatable using the keyboard, Switch Access, and TalkBack.
UX change announcements
Announce all UX changes (with live regions when possible)

All UX changes resulting from user action or automatic updates must be announced to accessibility services. Live regions announce changes to their value, including becoming visible, but not when they are hidden. Accessibility announcements can also be made with direct code, but that should be done sparingly.
Turn on TalkBack and activate the controls below for demonstrations.
Good example 1: Counter with accessibilityLiveRegion
Counter: %1d
Increment counter
Reset counter
Good example 2: Waiting indicator with accessibilityLiveRegion and announceForAccessibility
Wait 15 seconds
Waiting…
Waiting completed
Input error announcements
Input errors must be announced
Use live regions to announce when an input field enters an error state. Turn on TalkBack and activate the Submit button without entering any input text for an example.
Good example 1: Form with field errors announced
Enter your user name and passphrase.
All fields are required.
Full Name
Error: The Full Name field is required. Please supply your full name.
Passphrase
Error: The Passphrase field is required. Please supply a passphrase.
Submit
Pending results…
Successful results.
Text resizing and reflow
Text must resize and reflow based on device settings

Always use scaled pixel (sp) dimensions for text sizes or text will not scale properly when the font size setting changes. Always use layout_height=\"wrap_content\" rather than a fixed height or text may be cut off when it resizes. Do not set maxLines or ellipsize unless the complete text is also available in some way.

Examine the example texts below. In the device Settings app, select Accessibility, Text and display, and Font size (Google), or Accessibility, Visibility enhancements, and Font size and style (Samsung), and maximize the font size. Observe how the example texts below change (or does not) and how text can be truncated if laid out with a fixed height.
Bad example 1: Fixed text size in dp units
This text will not resize.
Bad example 2: Scaled text size in a fixed layout height
This text may get cut off and will not reflow.
Bad example 3: Scaled text size in an one-line, ellipsized view
This text ellipsizes to one line. It will not reflow.
Good example 4: Scaled text with layout_height=\"wrap_content\"
This text will resize and reflow properly.
Accessibility reading order
Accessibility reading order must be logical

Accessibility reading order is set left-to-right, top-to-bottom or in XML layout order, depending on the layout element. The only solid fix to achieve a logical reading order is to correctly arrange the XML elements and layout groupings. The accessibilityTraversalBefore and accessibilityTraversalAfter properties may be used to force a specific reading order, but they are not reliable.
Step through the screen with TalkBack for examples.
Bad example 1: Texts in an illogical reading order

The main text block is a column two-thirds of the width of the screen with the sidebar text column shown beside it. TalkBack should read each column in order, but will instead read each text block left-to-right, top-to-bottom, mixing the main text and sidebar texts illogically.
Main text
This is the first paragraph of the main text block.
This is the second paragraph of the main text block.
This is the third paragraph of the main text block.
Sidebar
This is the first sidebar paragraph.
This is the second sidebar paragraph.
Problematic example 2: Texts forced into a logical reading order with accessibilityTraversalAfter

TalkBack may read each of this example\'s texts in column order, because accessibilityTraversalAfter is designed to force proper sequencing of the text elements. However, the accessibility traversal properties do not work on all Android platforms and they create maintenance challenges in layout files. Avoid using this technique.
Good example 3: Texts arranged in a logical reading order through layout grouping
TalkBack will read each of this example\'s texts in column order, because layout elements properly organize the text elements.
Keyboard and accessibility focus order
Keyboard and accessibility focus order must be logical and contain no traps

Focus order is set left-to-right, top-to-bottom or in XML layout order, depending on the layout element. The best method to achieve a logical focus order is to correctly arrange the XML elements and layout groupings, but the nextFocusForward and accessibilityTraversalBefore / accessibilityTraversalAfter properties may work to force a specific focus order if necessary.
Tab through this screen with an external keyboard for demonstrations. Also, step through the screen with TalkBack for comparison.
Bad example 1: Controls in an illogical focus order
Problematic example 2: Controls forced into a logical focus order with nextFocusForward and accessibilityTraversalAfter

This example controls keyboard focus order using nextFocusForward and accessibility focus order using accessibilityTraversalAfter. The accessibility traversal properties are poorly supported across Android platforms and create maintenance challenges. Avoid this approach.
Good example 3: Controls in a logical focus order through layout grouping and nextFocusForward
This example controls accessibility and keyboard focus order through layout grouping, as well as using nextFocusForward for compatibility with older versions of Android.
Group 1
Checkbox 1a
Checkbox 1b
Group 2
Checkbox 2a
Checkbox 2b
Bad example 4: A keyboard focus trap

Improperly setting nextFocusForward can create a focus order loop. The third button below cannot be reached by tabbing from the other two, nor can the focus loop be escaped by back-tabbing. Use the up or down arrow keys to escape the focus trap.
First button
Second button (tabs to first)
Third button (can\'t be reached)
Example 4 first button clicked.
Example 4 second button clicked.
Example 4 third button clicked.
Arrow keys focus order
Set arrow key focus order when needed
Arrow keys normally select the next control in their direction. The nextFocusUp, nextFocusDown, nextFocusLeft, and nextForwardRight properties allow control over that order.
Use an external keyboard and arrow keys to move around this page.
OK example 1: Controls with implicit (default) focus order
From the top button, the down arrow key moves focus to the left-most button, as does the up arrow key from the bottom button.
Move left.
Move right.
Move up.
Move down.
Move left clicked.
Move right clicked.
Move up clicked.
Move down clicked.
Good example 2: Controls with explicit focus order
Left and right arrow keys move focus between the left-most and right-most buttons. Up and down arrow keys move focus between the top and bottom buttons.
Custom focus indicators
Increase focus visibility with custom focus indicators

By default, Android controls have low-contrast focus indicators. Focus color can be controlled globally to increase contrast by setting android:colorControlHighlight on the default theme. Alternatively, focus visibility can be controlled by setting a control\'s stroke color, background, or foreground with state list selectors, as shown here.
Tab through this page with an external keyboard to see default and improved focus indicators.
Problematic example 1: Default button focus indicator
Because this button uses the default system focus indicator, it technically conforms with WCAG 2.2 guidelines regarding focus visibility. However, it provides a poor user experience.
Default focus indicator
Example 1 (default focus indicator) button clicked.
Good example 2: Custom button focus indicator with app:strokeColor, app:strokeWidth, and color state list
Custom focus indicator
Example 2 (custom focus indicator) button clicked.
Good example 3: Custom focus indicator with android:background and drawable state list
Custom focus indicator
Good example 4: Custom focus indicators with android:foreground and drawable state list (API 23+)
Move right
Example 4 image button (Move right) clicked.
Custom focus indicator
Custom focus indicator
Custom focus indicator
Custom focus indicator
Animation control
Support all necessary animation controls
Animations can cause some people distraction or physical reactions. Any repeating animation should provide a convenient Pause, Stop, or Hide control.
Use the Pause/Play button to stop and restart the animation on this page.
All animations should honor the “Remove animations” setting, which is automatic in many cases, but not all.

To try the \"Remove animations\" setting, open the device Settings app, and select Accessibility, Color and motion (Google) or Accessibility, Visibility Enhancements (Samsung), depending on your Android version. Toggle the \"Remove animations\" setting on to stop the animations on this page.
Animated fading text
Pause
Play
Minimum touch target size
Touch target sizes should be at least 48dp by 48dp

WCAG 2.2 guidelines require that touch target sizes be a minimum of 24 by 24 CSS pixels and suggest at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels. Android Material Design guidelines suggest that touch target sizes be at least 48dp by 48dp.
Tap the example icon buttons below and note their relative ease or difficulty. The buttons are bordered to show their tap target area.
Bad example 1: A 16dp by 22dp icon button
Show more details.
Tapped the 16dp by 22dp icon button.
OK example 2: A 24dp by 24dp icon button
Show more details.
Tapped the 24dp by 24dp icon button.
Good example 3: A 48dp by 48dp icon button using minWidth and minHeight
Show more details.
Tapped the 48dp by 48dp icon button using minWidth and minHeight.
Good example 4: A 48dp by 48dp icon button using layout padding
Show more details.
Tapped the 48dp by 48dp icon button using layout padding.
Accessibility action labels
Enhance screen reader user experience by customizing standard action labels
How TalkBack describes the standard actions of a control (such as \“Double-tap to activate\” for buttons) can be partially overridden to be more useful.
Turn on TalkBack and select the following buttons to hear a demonstration.
OK example 1: Default click action label
Show details
Good example 2: Customized click action label
Show details
Show details
Custom state descriptions
Enhance screen reader user experience by customizing state description labels
How TalkBack describes the state of a control (such as \“Checked\” and \"Unchecked\" for check boxes) can be overridden to be more useful.
Turn on TalkBack and then select and toggle the following controls to hear demonstrations.
Note: This technique does not work on all platforms and API levels.
OK example 1: Checkbox with default state labels
Motion detector
Good example 2: Checkbox with customized state labels
Motion detector
Activated
Deactivated
OK example 3: Switch with default state labels
Shields
Good example 4: Switch with custom state and click labels
Shields
Raised
Lowered
Raise shields
Lower shields
Custom accessibility actions
Simplify screen reader user experience with custom accessibility actions
Turn on TalkBack and swipe through this page to hear demonstrations of cards with and without custom accessibility actions. Clicking on cards and buttons displays a snackbar message.
See details
Bad example 1: Card without custom accessibility actions
Note how each button must be read as a separate item in TalkBack before the next card is read. TalkBack does not read \"Actions available…\" on this card.
Like post: Card #1 (\"Card without custom accessibility actions\")
Share post: Card #1 (\"Card without custom accessibility actions\")
Report as inappropriate: Card #1 (\"Card without custom accessibility actions\")
Good example 2: Card with custom accessibility actions

Note how the card is read as a single item. Buttons have become custom accessibility actions; TalkBack reads \"Actions available…\" and one swipe takes you to the next card instead of to a button within the card.
Good example 3: Another card with custom accessibility actions
TalkBack also reads \"Actions available…\" on this card. Open the TalkBack menu and then the Actions menu to perform the buttons\' actions. Isn\'t that easier to use?
Like this post
Share this post
Report this post as inappropriate
Selected to show details of card #%1$d
Selected to like card #%1$d
Selected to share card #%1$d
Selected to report card #%1$d as inappropriate
Accordion controls
Accordion controls require an expand or collapse action

Accordion controls must present the appropriate expand or collapse action to the Android Accessibility API, in addition to any tap to toggle action. There are many ways to code these controls - as layout elements or list items, but all require this additional handling in order to announce their expanded/collapsed state.
Turn on TalkBack, navigate the page, and activate the controls for a demonstration. Listen for expanded/collapsed state announcement as well as special expand/collapse actions.
Bad example 1: Accordion without expand/collapse actions
Incorrect Accordion example, Item 1
Incorrect Accordion example, Item 2
Incorrect Accordion example, Item 3
Good example 2: Accordion with expand/collapse actions
Correct Accordion example, Item 1
Correct Accordion example, Item 2
Correct Accordion example, Item 3
Correct Accordion example, Item 4
Dropdown selection menus
Create dropdown selection menus with standard controls
The Spinner control and the Exposed Dropdown Menu pattern create accessible dropdown selection menus. Custom approaches are less likely to be accessible.
Turn on TalkBack and swipe through this page, activating each list control and making selections, in order to hear demonstrations of accessible dropdown lists.
Good example 1: Spinner control
Here a Spinner control is used to create an accessible dropdown selection menu. Note the TextView label associated with the Spinner using android:labelFor.
Example 1 item %1$s selected.
Payment type
Cash
Check
Credit/Debit card
Money order
Voucher
No payment type selected.
Good example 2: Exposed Dropdown Menu pattern
The Exposed Dropdown Menu pattern uses TextInputLayout and AutoCompleteTextView controls to create an accessible dropdown selection menu.
Example 2 item %1$s clicked.
Autocomplete input controls
Create autocomplete input fields with standard controls

The standard AutoCompleteTextView control creates an autocomplete input field: when text is typed, automatic completion suggestions will be displayed in a drop-down selection list. Custom approaches to autocompletion are likely to be less accessible.

In order to hear a demonstration, turn on TalkBack, activate either U.S. State autocomplete input control for editing, type text, and make selections. (The ZIP Code fields are not auto-complete input controls.)
Good example 1: AutoCompleteTextView control
Example 1 item %1$s clicked.
Good example 2: AutoCompleteTextView in TextInputLayout
Example 2 item %1$s clicked.
U.S. State
ZIP Code
No State name selected.
Submit
Autofill input fields
Supply known values to input fields

Whenever possible, supply known data values to input fields to reduce redundant input. This should be done in two ways: via android:autofillHints and by defaulting known application data into field values.
Focusing into the input fields below may offer autofill suggestions, depending on your device\'s Android version, selected Autofill service, and its configuration settings.
Good example 1: Name and password with autofill hints
Name
Password
Good example 2: Address fields with autofill hints and in-app default values
Fill in the Shipping Address fields and select Next. The matching Billing Address fields will default to the Shipping data entered.
Shipping Address
Street Address
City
State
ZIP Code
Next
Billing Address
Previous
Keyboard type
Match keyboard type to input data
Input fields should configure a keyboard type appropriate to the data they accept. An inappropriate keyboard type can make data entry harder or even impossible.
Select each field below for editing and observe the soft keyboard type displayed.
Bad example 1: Numeric keyboard type prevents text data entry
Name
Problematic example 2: Keyboard type (text) allows full data entry, but is not specific to the field type
Name
Good example 3: Keyboard type for names (textPersonName)
Name
Good example 4: Keyboard type for phone number (phone)
Phone
Good example 5: Keyboard type for decimal number (numberDecimal)
Amount
Good example 6: Keyboard type for email (textEmailAddress)
Email
Good example 7: Keyboard type for URL (textUri)
URL
Good example 8: Keyboard type for sentences (textCapSentences)
Description
Good example 9: Keyboard type for dates (date)
Date
Good example 10: Keyboard type for times (time)
Time
Good example 11: Keyboard type for datetimes (datetime)
Datetime
Links inline with text
Creating links inline with text

Links inline with text can be created using HTML anchor tags in string resources or URLSpans. The TextView movementMethod must also be set to a LinkMovementMethod. Links will appear in the TalkBack menu\'s Links dialog.

Turn on TalkBack and navigate the page text for a demonstration. Note the pauses around the inline linked texts. Listen for the \"Links available\" action notifications, tap with 3-fingers to open the TalkBack menu, and select \"Links\" to see a dialog containing the available links. Pick a link to open a web view displaying the linked page.
Good example 1: Using an HTML anchor tag
Correct inline link example 1: Using an HTML anchor tag
This paragraph contains a link using an HTML anchor tag to an older tutorial about how to create clickable links in a TextView on Android.
Good example 2: Using URLSpan
Correct inline link example 2: Using URLSpan
This paragraph contains links created using URLSpan, including a Google Support article.
Text language identification
Identify the text language when necessary

If an app presents mixed language texts, it must identify the language of each block of text that differs from the system default language using LocaleSpan. Otherwise, the text-to-speech engine underlying TalkBack will mispronounce words, often substantially.
The same problem applies to apps with internal language controls and to mono-lingual apps used when a different device language is selected.
Turn on TalkBack and listen closely to how the example texts below are enunciated by the screen reader.
Bad example 1: Mixed language text without language identification
Good example 2: Mixed language text with LocaleSpan
The phrase \"plus ça change, plus c\'est la même chose\" translates to English as \"the more things change, the more they stay the same.\"
Good example 3: Custom view for texts with specific locales
Spanish:
German:
